instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Seems like it has been cleaned by another company. Slight oxidation residue around <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R3091</RESISTOR>.
Measurements around CD32s seems fine. No short anywhere.

T2 seems getting slightly warm.
[ATTACH type="full" width="410px" alt="1698532017071.jpeg"]61334[/ATTACH]
Tried DFU both with keyboard comb and <SIGNAL>FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> pads to 1.8 PP1V8_SLP2SR_PMUVDDGPIO which is nearby. i can measure 1.8V od <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL>, but no luck being detected under Apple Configurator

When connected to Apple configurator with <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> jumper wire without battery or power supply, only on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> gets warm, while <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is not warming when connected to Apple Configurator via bottom USBc. Although no indication of any corrosions there, shall I replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>?

Where to start?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Check all adjacent traces and resistors of <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.

All <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s LDOs present?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Traces on the TBT ROM seems fine. 
[ATTACH type="full" width="406px"]61335[/ATTACH]

LDO's are present apart than <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V - Not sure if this needs to be on at this stage.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
1V1 LDO BMC must appear only on the powered port.

Did you check all resistors connected to <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>?
You've said to got one with oxidation.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Sorry I must have not been clear. The one with oxidation was <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>. I have taken it out and cleaned underneath as it had bad solder joint on pin1
[ATTACH type="full" width="603px" alt="1698623060827.png"]61336[/ATTACH]

<RESISTOR>R3091</RESISTOR> on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> looked like it had a corrosion marks. I was thinking it might have leaked under <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and was thinking to reball. But it is slight, compared to the ones with liquid I've seen before and CD32 still been ok.


"1V1 LDO BMC must appear only on the powered port." - is this on 20V turned on machine with CD32 engaged or when power is connected. Currently I dont get it on either of CD32's when 5V 0.23A


Everything seems fine around the TBT rom. No corrosion there, also MISO, WPL, SC seems to output at 3.3V range

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Also want confirm if this is the expected behaviour? Could this be a cause of the system not getting detected under Apple Configurator. Maybe faulty <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> or its circuit

This is with <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> jumper.
When connected to the top USBc <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
[ATTACH type="full" width="584px"]61337[/ATTACH]

When connecte dto the bottom USBc <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
[ATTACH type="full" width="577px"]61338[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Seems to have problems on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> area.
1V1 LDO BMC is required for the communication between charger and the laptop.
If missing, the charger voltage can't be adjusted.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Thanks. I have replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> with another one still stuck at 5V 0.23A on both ports.
Still missing <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> . Only different now under IR is that both ports seems to heat up T2 evenly, unlike before.

Looking at the bootup sequence - [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3215_Bootup_Sequence[/URL] I went and replaced the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> thinking that might be a corrupted code. I got it from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> but older gen (2018) and still same.

Also not detected under DFU with or without the <SIGNAL>SOC_DFU_FORCE</SIGNAL>


Not sure if means anything but I get a DIM White LED near the battery connector on only on AC adapter, but not on battery.
LED seems to reflect to <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_LED</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message: Check if <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> delivers correctly SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Yes all SLPS2R are present from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>
CPUAWAKE are at 0.75V
SRAMAWAKE is at 0.8V
1.2,  1.8, 3,3 and 0.7 VDDCPU awake as well are present

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
It should enter DFU then.

Did you test disconnecting auido flex?
Remove and inspect audio board for corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
yes tested with only bare board with <SIGNAL>SOC_DFU_FORCE</SIGNAL> pull up to 1.8V. Also in the case with disconnected audio and battery only. 

There is no oxidation residue apart than <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>. But again it seems to be washed with something like aerosol can as feels oily.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message:
Be sure to follow all steps to put the machine in DFU mode.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL]

Sometime is very difficult to get it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.2A.
threads.message: I can see it gets to it. When I connect the usbc meter to the top port and Apple conf to the bottom one, closer to the trackpad. The usbc meter reboots after 10sec with the keyboard shortcut to DFU.
